comment.author: 43854658@N00
comment._content:
This appears to be a Dining Car (Restaurante) of the Portuguese Railway Company (CP), and part of the famous Sud Express.
"Sud Express is the name of a famous night train connection originally between Paris and Lisbon, but now covering only the southern part of the traditional route. The trip used to take two nights. "In its first days of existence at the beginning of the 20th century Sud Express formed, together with Nord Express, a direct link between Saint Petersburg, Russia and Lisbon, Portugal with connecting ships to South America and North America. "For many years a branch of the Sud Express reached Madrid too, actually gathering more passengers than the Lisbon one."
The car is managed by the European Great Expresses Company – an international hotel and travel logistics company founded in 1872, and particularly known for their on-train catering and sleeping-car services. The well-known crest in the center of the car is that of the European Great Expresses Company (Companhia Internacional das Carruagens-Camas (e dos Grandes Expressos Europeus):      CIWL Crest

comment.author: 35855390@N03
comment._content:
Não é uma Carruagem Camas.
É uma Carruagem Restaurante.
Mais concretamente uma das ex Salão Pulman, Etoile du Nord, que foram transformadas em carruagem Restaurante e usadas durante muitos anos no percurso ibérico do Sud Express.

comment.realname: Biblioteca de Arte / Art Library Fundação Calouste Gulbenkian

comment._content:
Caro Fernando,
obrigado pela precisão relativamente ao tipo de carruagem de que se trata.
Cumprimentos

comment.author: 31050741@N07
comment._content: Oi! Sou administrador de um grupo chamado CIWL e nós adoraríamos ter isto adicionado ao grupo!

comment.author: 32253634@N05
comment._content: I would like to let you know that this coach was originally a Pullman car of the CIWL in service between Paris - Brussels and Amsterdam, later probably on other french lines, converted as a dining car after the WW II and finally transferred to Spain and Portugal and converted to the iberic gauge.   Beautiful photo. Is this car now safe somewhere ?
